 Thank you.

So, last year, I came here to talk about a couple of things about graphing and just analytics.
But then, you know, when I came back, I started thinking about all the other things that are
beneficial before even going forward for, you know, talking about analytics is to understand

So, today, we're gonna be talking about data and also the data attack framework.
So, you guys already heard from me.

to talk about, you know, health and all these things.
So, and I'm also a former Capital One Senior Threat Hunter in Virginia.
And that is where I started also working with a lot of, I would say, data.
Like, more than, you know, 300,000 endpoints and, you know, then including the cloud.
So, I think that, you know, that was also an experience to know exactly, you know, how
it goes from 10,000, 2,000 endpoints all the way to a massive amount of data.
Hi, everyone.
My name is Jose.
I go by CyberPanda on Twitter.
I'm currently a cybersecurity student at Northern Virginia Community College in the US.
I like to contribute to open source projects with my brother.
And also a former Senior Business Intelligence Analyst from UNASEN Peru.
Yep.
Oh, and you can follow me in CyberWarDoc.
Sorry.
I didn't mention that.
Okay.
So, the agenda for today.
We're going to be talking about a little bit, you know, threat hunting programs with data.
All the way to start, you know, coming out with a methodology to start mapping your Windows
event logs or your, you know, security in general, security event logs in general to
the attack framework, for example.
And then we're going to talk about a little bit about Mordor at the end.
And you guys are going to know why in a little bit.
So, threat hunting and data.
So, I believe that a lot of organizations are doing this already, right?
They're putting together their programs, they're doing all the way from the pre-hunt activities
all the way to defining their hypothesis analytics, hunting, you know, reporting, all the way
to enhancing security controls.
Everybody's doing that already, right?
The problem that I see a lot every time I go to a company is that they focus so much
on that, you know, but they don't focus at all into this problem that they have.
Which is there's a lot of data.
There's a lot of data that is being generated that if you don't understand exactly what
that data is, then it's hard to implement all the other processes that you have in there.
Some other organizations are even skipping some of the steps on their own programs and
they're just giving a console, a search bar to a security analyst and say go and hunt.
And all they do is they just Google, they find a script or they find a specific query,
they run it and they just call it a day and they say this is a hunting engagement.
So, there's a lot of things going on, right?
All the way from a basic program, all the way to just giving a search bar.
But at the end of the day, if you don't care about your data, it doesn't matter what you're
doing, talent, technology, it doesn't matter if you're the best at hunting.
If you have a data swamp rather than a data lake, it's going to be very, very hard to
even do your job.
And I have experienced that.
I actually have performed IR and also hunting engagements on that and it's not fun at all.
It is very painful and a lot of people just get frustrated because that's one of the biggest
problems out there.
We talk about how to do, you know, procedures, how to put together your program, some nice
slides about how you can link different teams together and all this stuff, you know, work
together with a red team.
It's amazing, right?
But in reality, when you go to your organization, that's the problem at the end.
And that's going to, of course, define if you're going to be successful or not.
So you might be asking yourself, okay, so more data, then more problems.
Yes and no.
So if you have data, it's going to be great if you're going to do an investigation, if
you're going to use it to, you know, find anomalies, outliers and things like that.
But at the same time, you have to understand what it is that you're actually collecting.
And when I asked this question, it actually has another question, which is, do you know
what you're collecting?
And do you know what data you're collecting?
Two different questions.
Because when I said, do you know what you're collecting?
The answers are, yes, I'm collecting process monitoring.
I use my EDR, I use Sysmon, I'm collecting all this.
My question is, no, no, but do you really know what you're collecting?
What is the data behind those data categories or names that you have in an Excel sheet?
You know, what's going on with those events?
Do you understand exactly what's under that?
And most of the time, the answer is no.
So how you might be doing it to start at least getting a little bit closer to talking about
data and also your hunting engagements.
So a lot of organizations that we go to, right, MITRE ATT&CK came last year to talk about,

And some organizations that I go to, they say, hey, I have an idea.
MITRE ATT&CK has this, you know, metadata called data sources.
And I can start mapping all my controls to those data sources that are going to map to

So easy.

a information collected by a sensor in order to allow you, you know, to validate a detection

And you can just start doing this.
